results.title: The Lucky years
results.creator_credit: Brian Luscombe and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Brian Luscombe enlisted in the Air Force on Australia Day 1942. He was 18 and wanted to be a pilot. Dubbed Lucky Luscombe, Brian talks about his years as a pilot in the RAAF in World War II.
results.description: Brian Luscombe enlisted in the Air Force on Australia Day 1942. He was 18 and wanted to be a pilot. Dubbed Lucky Luscombe, Brian talks about his years as a pilot in the RAAF in World War II.

results.title: When quiet came
results.creator_credit: Bill Flowers and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Bill Flowers tells his story of how he was captured by the Japanese and sent to Changi as a POW. His tale is one of survival. Bill was in the 2/9th Field Ambulance during World War II. This digital story was recorded as part of In Our Words : Stories from Victorian Veterans digital storytelling workshop.
results.description: Bill Flowers tells his story of how he was captured by the Japanese and sent to Changi as a POW. His tale is one of survival. results.title: Big fish
results.creator_credit: Tim Burton, Dan Jinks, Bruce Cohen, Richard Zanuck, Zanuck Company, Cohen Company, Jinks and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Adapted from Daniel Wallace’s novel “Big Fish: A Novel of Mythic Proportions” comes Tim Burton’s twentieth feature film since his directorial debut in 1971. “Big Fish” is a sentimental exploration of the ambiguous line between fact and fiction, as a man (Billy Crudup) makes a final attempt at getting to know his dying father (Albert Finney). Mythical tall tales told to the man repeatedly throughout his life by his father are revealed to the viewer with Ewan McGregor playing the father as a young man. A departure from Burton’s traditionally darker oeuvre “Big Fish” challenges notions that truth should be pursued before an embellished reality. Cast includes Jessica Lange and Helena Bonham Carter. Nominated for four Golden Globe Awards.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tim Burton, Dan Jinks, Bruce Cohen, Richard Zanuck, Zanuck Company, Cohen Company, Jinks and Columbia Pictures

holdings.name: ISO; ACMI Digital Access Copy - presentation

results.title: Kiss or kill [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Bill Bennett, Jennifer Bennett, Bill Bennett Productions, Movievision, South Australian Film Corporation, Australian Asset Management and AFFC
results.brief_description: Nikki (Frances O’Connor) and Al (Matt Day) are lovers and small time scammers. When a routine job leaves a man dead in a hotel room, they decide to head west across the barren Nullarbor Plain carrying a video showing football hero Zipper Doyle (Barry Langrishe), in an intimate moment. With the cops (Chris Haywood and Andrew S. Gilbert) on their tail, they stay overnight at a motel. Next morning the motel owner (Max Cullen) is dead; murdered. Fleeing further into the desert, the two suspects are given shelter by an eccentric couple at their isolated shack. By morning, they too are murdered. Nikki and Al begin to suspect each other of the multiple killings and start learning things about each other they wished they never knew. Meanwhile, with the assistance of an Aboriginal tracker, the cops are closing in.

results.title: The Interview [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Craig Monahan, Bill Hughes, Interview Films and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: A haunting feature debut from Craig Monahan which explores the complex psychological exchange between Detective Sergeant John Steele (Tony Martin) and nervy suspected murderer Eddie Fleming (Hugo Weaving) during the hours of a claustrophobic police interrogation.The apparently ordinary Fleming is asleep in his apartment when his door is broken down and he is accused of nameless crimes. He is the only lead the tough, world weary Detective Sergeant Steele has and so begins a bewildering sequence of interviews where the crime and the many forces at work between the characters and their situation gradually becomes apparent. The nature of guilt, innocence and who or what to believe is rendered uncertain in this film as we are presented not with any concrete answers but with the fluidity of perception and the difficulties of defining truth. (Awards: Winner Best Original Screenplay, Best Film and Best Actor (Hugo Weaving) Australian Film Institute Awards, 1998)

results.title: Bootmen [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Dein Perry, Hilary Linstead and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Loosely based on director Dein Perry’s early life as a dancer, “Bootmen” is the story of two brothers - Sean (Adam Garcia) and Mitchell (Sam Worthington) - working in a steel mill in the industrial city of Newcastle. Both dream of one day escaping from the mill, Sean as a tap dancer in Sydney and Mitchell purchasing a tow truck to get out of the only life their stern father has ever known. Tension arrises between the brothers when Sean quits the mill to go to Sydney to study with a well known dance troupe and Mitchell moves in on Sean’s woman, Linda (Sophie Lee), both brothers finding themselves in love with her. “Bootmen” is a feel-good movie that is similar in genre to “Strictly Ballroom” and “The Full Monty”, a touching and sweet film with wonderful tap dancing sequences. Cast also includes William Zappa, Richard Carter and Susie Porter.

results.title: Malcolm [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Nadia Tass, David Parker and Cascade Films
results.brief_description: Malcolm, a simple genius played by Colin Friels, loses his job at a Melbourne tram depot after building his own one-man tram and taking to the streets. With funds dwindling, Malcolm is forced to take in a lodger, a small time criminal who moves in with girlfriend, Judith. Frank soon realizes that Malcolm’s mechanical wizardry can help his career - the result - a series of oddball but unsuccessful robberies that culminates in the heist of the decade that stretches Malcolm’s devises to the full. “Malcolm” was critically acclaimed world wide and received eight AFI Awards including best director and best film.

results.title: Chopper [DVD] (D)
results.creator_credit: Andrew Dominik, Michele Bennett and Palace Films
results.brief_description: This AFI award winning film is based on the life of Mark Brandon - “Chopper” - Read, a notorious Australian criminal who became a best selling author, publishing 9 books of his life and times as a key stand man in Melbourne’s underworld. Eric Bana plays Chopper following his conviction for abducting a judge who was proceeding over the case of his best friend, Jimmy Loughnan (Simon Lyndon). Read ends up serving a 16 year sentence for his efforts, during which he shares a cell with Jimmy and has to contend with Keithy George (David Field), a crime boss who runs the prison. After an attack of violence instigated by Chopper, he kills Keithy and finds himself the target of numerous prisoners wishing revenge on him. As he sees it, the only way to escape the notorious H division is to get his friend to chop his ears off so that he can be transferred to another prison. Eight years later, Chopper is released and finds himself battling his own personal demons and psychotic episodes to try and adjust to outside life. All he can focus on is seeking revenge on arch enemy Neville Bartos (Vince Colosimo) and looking out for his girlfriend, Tanya (Kate Beahan). This special edition includes deleted scenes, theatrical trailer and footage of director Andrew Dominik and Eric Bana’s visit to Chopper in Tasmania while researching the film.

results.title: The Sum of us [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Geoff Burton, Kevin Dowling, Hal McElroy, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Southern Star Entertainment
results.brief_description: Harry (Jack Thompson) is a widower whose life centres around getting his gay son, Jeff (Russell Crowe), to settle down with a nice man. They live together in working-class Sydney, sharing a home, a few beers and a shared bemusement about the rites of masculinity (both straight and queer) in the post-sexual revolution 1990s. Based on David Steven’s award-winning play, “The Sum of Us” is a wonderful comedy about sons and fathers, a loving tribute to the tenderness and comraderie that can be found between men. Though some gay and lesbian critics disliked the film because of its obvious stage-bound script and the unashamed masculinity of Crowe’s gay son, by focussing on working class rather than bourgeois sexuality, “The Sum of Us” can also be seen as a film that radically redefines the boundaries of Australian masculinity and sexuality. Crowe makes a handsome and likeable central character and Jack Thompson is wonderful as the committed, generous father willing to do whatever it takes to make his son happy.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Geoff Burton, Kevin Dowling, Hal McElroy, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Southern Star Entertainment
results.description: Harry (Jack Thompson) is a widower whose life centres around getting his gay son, Jeff (Russell Crowe), to settle down with a nice man. They live together in working-class Sydney, sharing a home, a few beers and a shared bemusement about the rites of masculinity (both straight and queer) in the post-sexual revolution 1990s. Based on David Steven’s award-winning play, “The Sum of Us” is a wonderful comedy about sons and fathers, a loving tribute to the tenderness and comraderie that can be found between men. Though some gay and lesbian critics disliked the film because of its obvious stage-bound script and the unashamed masculinity of Crowe’s gay son, by focussing on working class rather than bourgeois sexuality, “The Sum of Us” can also be seen as a film that radically redefines the boundaries of Australian masculinity and sexuality. Crowe makes a handsome and likeable central character and Jack Thompson is wonderful as the committed, generous father willing to do whatever it takes to make his son happy.

They live together in working-class Sydney, sharing a home, a few beers and a shared bemusement about the rites of masculinity (both straight and queer) in the post-sexual revolution 1990s. Based on David Steven’s award-winning play, “The Sum of Us” is a wonderful comedy about sons and fathers, a loving tribute to the tenderness and comraderie that can be found between men. Though some gay and lesbian critics disliked the film because of its obvious stage-bound script and the unashamed masculinity of Crowe’s gay son, by focussing on working class rather than bourgeois sexuality, “The Sum of Us” can also be seen as a film that radically redefines the boundaries of Australian masculinity and sexuality. Crowe makes a handsome and likeable central character and Jack Thompson is wonderful as the committed, generous father willing to do whatever it takes to make his son happy.
